ul_647645: How to extract every 10th frame from a video?
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_647645: ffmpeg -i out1.avi -r 0.1 -f image2 image-%3d.jpeg

ffmpeg -i out1.mp4 -vf "select=not(mod(n\,10))" -vsync vfr image_%03d.jpg

Explanations about Options.-loglevel: Set logging level and flags used by the library.
Explanations about Options.-t:
When used as an input option (before "-i"), limit the duration of data read from the
 input file.
Explanations about Options.-vf: Create the filtergraph specified by filtergraph and use it to filter the stream.
Explanations about Options.-ss:
When used as an input option (before "-i"), seeks in this input file to position. Note
 that in most formats it is not possible to seek exactly, so ffmpeg will seek to the
 closest seek point before position. When transcoding and -accurate_seek is enabled
 (the default), this extra segment between the seek point and position will be decoded
 and discarded. When doing stream copy or when -noaccurate_seek is used, it will be
 preserved.
Explanations about Options.-vsync:
Video sync method. For compatibility reasons old values can be specified as numbers.
 Newly added values will have to be specified as strings always.
Explanations about Options.-n:
Do not overwrite output files, and exit immediately if a specified output file already
 exists.

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_44389090: Extract metadata from multiple videos
su_594008: Bash script to extract audio from video
Top-3 Scripts:
su_594008: #!/bin/bash
FOLDER_SRC="/home/J/Music/TestBatchConv"
find "$FOLDER_SRC" -type f -print0 | while IFS= read -r -d '' myvid; do
  echo "Trying to convert $myvid"
  avconv -i "$myvid" -c:a libmp3lame -q:a 4 "${myvid%.*}.mp3" 2>/dev/null || echo "$myvid is not a valid file."
done

au_685174: avconv -i $file -map 0:0 -map 0:2 -acodec copy -vcodec copy $outfile

dir="*.avi"
for file in $dir
do 
 avconv -i $file -map 0:0 -map 0:2 -acodec copy -vcodec copy $outfile
done

Explanations about Options.-d: Prints internal debugging information to stderr.
Explanations about Options.-p:
On systems that support utime(3) or utimes(2), attempt to preserve the access time
 of files analyzed, to pretend that file never read them.
Explanations about Options.-c:
Cause a checking printout of the parsed form of the magic file. This is usually
 used in conjunction with the -m flag to debug a new magic file before installing it.
Explanations about Options.-e:
Exclude the test named in testname from the list of tests made to determine the file
 type. Valid test names are:
Explanations about Options.-m:
Specify an alternate list of files and directories containing magic. This can be a
 single item, or a colon-separated list. If a compiled magic file is found alongside
 a file or directory, it will be used instead.
Explanations about Options.-v: Print the version of the program and exit.

Top-3 Similar Questions: su_594008: Bash script to extract audio from video
Top-3 Scripts:
su_594008: #!/bin/bash
FOLDER_SRC="/home/J/Music/TestBatchConv"
find "$FOLDER_SRC" -type f -print0 | while IFS= read -r -d '' myvid; do
  echo "Trying to convert $myvid"
  avconv -i "$myvid" -c:a libmp3lame -q:a 4 "${myvid%.*}.mp3" 2>/dev/null || echo "$myvid is not a valid file."
done

Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_246419: Open file with started vim from outside (in terminal)
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_246419: vim --remote

vim --servername VIM [filename ...]

vim --remote-tab file.txt

vim --remote-send ":tabfind filename.txt<CR>"

vim --remote-tab `find $PWD -name build.xml`

vim --servername HAMBURGER # Start new session named "HAMBURGER"
vim --servername HAMBURGER --remote-tab `find $PWD -name BACON`

Explanations about Options.-e: Start Vim in Ex mode, just like the executable was called "ex".
Explanations about Options.-m:
Modifying files is disabled. Resets the 'write' option. You can still modify
 the buffer, but writing a file is not possible.
Explanations about Options.--servername:
Use {name} as the server name. Used for the current Vim, unless used with a
 --remote argument, then it's the name of the server to connect to.
Explanations about Options.-n:
No swap file will be used. Recovery after a crash will be impossible. Handy
 if you want to edit a file on a very slow medium (e.g. floppy). Can also be
 done with ":set uc=0". Can be undone with ":set uc=200".

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_31710647: How to start interactive ssh terminal from bash script?

Explanations about Options.-l:
Specifies the user to log in as on the remote machine. This also may be specified
 on a per-host basis in the configuration file.
Explanations about Options.-t:
Force pseudo-terminal allocation. This can be used to execute arbitrary screen-
 based programs on a remote machine, which can be very useful, e.g. when implementing
 menu services. Multiple -t options force tty allocation, even if ssh has no local
 tty.

Top-3 Scripts:
so_7376477: curl | head

curl --silent http://www.jhepple.com/support/SampleMovies/MPEG-2.mpg \
  | head --bytes 10K > temp.mpg
mediainfo '--Inform=Video;%Width%x%Height%' temp.mpg

Explanations about Options.--silent:
Silent or quiet mode. Don't show progress meter or error messages. Makes Curl
 mute. It will still output the data you ask for, potentially even to the
 terminal/stdout unless you redirect it.
